documents.title: mike figgis is leaving las guardian
text: guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 2:14pm this has been very interesting for me .
i enjoy this format - it gives me time to think .
the questions have been very interesting , thank you .
bye ! just a reminder - the 36 dramatic situations is out now and available everywhere .
the cards kickstart on monday !
kamatron asks : how much rewriting went into joe eszterhas 's one night stand script , which he allegedly got paid $ 4m for , and how did it differ from the finished product ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 2:06pm my version of one night stand is so different from mr eszterhas 's that he asked to have his name taken off the project .
i think new line felt they 'd been landed with an expensive turkey and i was hot that week , just after leaving las vegas .
they offered it to me , i read it , did n't like it , they said i could do what i liked with it .
one of my favourite films is truffault 's the woman next door - i think it is his best film .
and i always wanted to do an english language version of it , so this was a big influence on my rewrite .
i originally offered it to nicholas cage , but i could n't see him for dust , and i was very happy with wesley snipes 's amazing performance .
it is one of my favourite films , of my own .
it got a terrible critical pasting in the states , but fared much better in europe .
talking of writing ( cheap segue into my new book ) , the 36 dramatic situations is a rewrite of a french theatre classic written in the late 19th century .
i thought it was vital to update this interesting concept for cinema .
in a way , i could describe it as 36 essays on the differences between film and theatre ; something that aspiring screenwriters need to be aware of .
also the book examines cliched attitudes , particularly towards gender ( the dominate male , the submissive female ) , as well as race and religion .
the book clearly reminds us that `` drama comes directly from the original greek drama and biblical morality '' .
the family is a huge deal in the book .

given the fact that there are supposedly 36 dramatic situations , i developed a pack of cards which enable the writer to use the element of chance in the creative process - take three cards , and then place them in a sequence and let your imagination run wild .

i 've used the cards extensively over the last year , and what is fascinating is that i find myself in areas of drama that i would never normally choose , and it has opened up so many possibilities in terms of pure storytelling.the book comes out this week , but i 've had to develop the cards myself via kickstarter and the campaign begins next monday .

documents.title: 'actors give their best work when they share responsibility '
text: quickspace asks : do you think that some of the craft of film-making has been lost due to the simplification of the process through things like cgi ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 1:54pm good point .
i always get my best results in limited situations , ie : low budget or short schedule .
actors tend to give their best work when they share some of the responsibility .
with major features these days , there is so much overload of technology that one smells actors phoning it in .
and i hope they got well paid for it .
but they do come across as being passengers , rather than participants .
this has been an inevitable consequence of studios aligning themselves with the gaming industry , the comic book industry and the boyish culture of mainstream american narrative .
i think it is a loss cause , and a battle not worth fighting .

cinema can go in many interesting directions that have nothing to do with this , but like i say , often ( like a dripping tap ) , until we deal with a major revolution with distribution and all of the interesting elements that can suggest , nothing much is going to change .
quickspace asks : what 's the secret to a successful adaptation ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 1:47pm under the volcano ( john huston ) worked for me .
they took a section of that very dense , lowry novel and that was the film .
novels usually do n't make good films .
it is too difficult to condense .
but a good novel would fit far more successfully into the new long form tv format .

some years ago , i explored the possibility of adapting donna tartt 's the little friend , but i heard on the grapevine that she 'd been so disheartened by the studio shenanigans around her first novel the secret history that she was no longer interested .
with leaving las vegas , i took a specific approach .
i xeroxed the novel and cut into scenes , and then made three piles : 1 ) could work in a film , 2 ) might but not sure where , and 3 ) absolutely not .
i pasted everything in the 1 ) pile and wrote some transitions , left it for a couple of months , did a second pass where i started using some of the 2 ) pile .
by the end , i was dipping into the 3 ) and using that material for the scenes with elisabeth shue and her therapist .
quickspace asks : do you have any guilty pleasures in regards to big franchise films ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 1:40pm absolutely .
fred astaire and ginger rogers , particularly in the light of certain recent successes within that genre .
when i teach film , i show a clip of fred and ginger and point out that they are dancing , singing , and acting all at the same time .
not only that , it seems to be sublime poetry .
i do n't think it has ever been equalled .
and when i research the technology that was involved , i am in awe of what was achieved .
this was a high spot in the history of film .

documents.title: 'i do n't feel cinema has progressed much in the last 70 years '
text: mediadope asks : timecode was an interesting experiment .
but was it a creative dead end ?

guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 1:31pm i think timecode was a clear indication of a direction that cinema could go in , an alternative to the deadening retirement home of the three act structure .
for me , it was a delightful experience , one that i 'd like to repeat in another form .
something that retrieved the great possibilities of live performance , the great possibilities of cinema .
if i am honest , i do n't feel that cinema has really progressed much in the last 70 years .
there have been positive moments like the nouvelle vague and the dogme movement .

but only two days ago i was reading a review of the blu-ray release of abel gance 's `` napoleon '' , which makes you realise how little cinema has focused on forward momentum , but has remained obsessed with the business of show .
which is not to say that great stuff has n't come out of cinema , it has .
but i remain as interested in experimentation and development as when i was working in performance art .
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 1:36pm just adding to that - timecode presented a radical alternative to linear narrative storytelling .

it was essentially a work in progress , and the basic idea has , of course , been commercially taken up by shows like 24 ( who acknowledge the influence ) , but the confusion about timecode stems from trying to compare it to things like russian ark and the impressive victoria - both of which were conventional films , without edits .
technically impressive , and with good acting , but timecode was n't attempting to do that .
it was really about the interplay between four visual elements in conjunction with specific sound editing - a different animal .
napoleon review silent-era epic more thrilling than ever read more
flmjet asks : in most of your later work you act as the cinematographer as well as director ¦ why is that ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 1:27pm when i first started making films , i felt sidelined .
i was watching television and the actors were relating to the cinematographer .
the cinematographers sometimes are very powerful and felt that they owned this territory .
a lovely french cinematographer , jean francois robin ( betty blue ) , shot the browning version for me .
at a certain point , he suggested that i operate the second camera .
it was a revelation .
suddenly , i had contact with the actors .
my next film was leaving las vegas .
i owned a 16-mm aaton camera and declan quinn , my dp , was open to the idea of 16-mm and me , operating second camera .
this was a great experience .
i have n't really looked back from that .
i have operated the camera on every film ever since .
35-mm , 16-mm , super 8 video , etc .
i 'm about to shoot a short film which is one of the sequences in the feature i love rotterdam .
i will be shooting on 16-mm .
i will be recording sound on an analogue tape recorder , the legendary nagra .
i do n't feel it adds to the work load .
i 'd rather be working than watching tv .
tommyboy79 asks : you got the best performance of nic cage 's career out of him .
what 's your approach with actors ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 1:22pm i was an actor , albeit in working performance art environments .
and also as a musician , i am aware of the dynamic between performer and audience - and how scary that can be , as well as exhilarating .
i work on the assumption that all actors can act .
the question is : are they the right actor ?
and what is their tempo and dynamic ?
some actors get there quickly , first take ; other actors take much longer .
you have to be sympathetic to the individual needs of the actors , at the same time aware of the ticking clock .
so deciding went to `` help '' the actor becomes a crucial decision .
every situation is different .
ultimately , i like actors , and this helps .
artmod asks : do you still use your fig rig ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 1:17pm good question .
i use it all the time .
and have spent the last two months redesigning and updating it , based on using a 15-mm bar system , combining it with bits of equipment acquired cheaply from the internet .

and it has been a revelation.i 'm using it with a canon c300 and the new nikon d5 , adding follow focus and a 7-inch monitor and it is working beautifully.i 'm talking to manfrotto about relaunching it and if not them , would love to find a small british company and stay local .
tommyboy79 asks : what would your advice would be for someone making their first low-budget feature how do you make that creative leap , and what do you base it on ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 1:14pm i appreciate how difficult this is .
david lynch suggests you go fishing and wait until something bites , then take it from there .
jakestockwell asks : as you 're an exponent of the trumpet and an appreciative follower of jazz , who winds up most often in your cd player ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 1:13pm clifford brown is a jazz trumpet player , who combines technique with poetry .
i love him on ballads .
miles is always there , as is louis armstrong .
have been listening to a lot of maria callas .
sometimes i listen to resonance radio - there is often some surprising music that i have n't heard before .
i have just done an interesting recording for radio 3 , for the show essential classics , which goes out the first week of july .
i tried to come up with a really eclectic list of 12 tracks - charles ives , 4th of july is pretty amazing and probably the most avant garde piece of classical music i have ever heard .
shhhhhh asks : 1 .
how do you construct characters and give their dialogue purpose ? 2 .
how do you bring together ideas in the final act of your scripts ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 1:09pm 1 ) good question .
i like to spend enough time so that characters can present themselves to me .
then their dialogue seems more organic , rather than expositional .
exposition is sometimes necessary , but not as necessary as a lot of writers seem to think .
in my new book , the 36 dramatic situations , i open with a quote from bergman : `` cinema is the ongoing exploration of the human face '' .
and therefore exposition can be a visual event , rather than some hokey dialogue.2 ) i wish i had a quick answer for this .
final act resolution is the supreme test of a writer .
i notice in the new 'mecca ' of tv long form drama , this various problem has most definitely not gone away .
one witnesses the same desperate attempts to land the big jumbo jet because the fuel is running out.i think this mode of indulgence is something to be very wary of .
one could compare it to the advent of the 12- inch vinyl in the 1950s , where we went from the perfect 3 and a half minutes to the idea you could take 20 minutes for a solo .
which was fine for charlie parker and john coltrane , but extremely painful and boring for many of the disciples .
unprinted asks : i liked your 1984 film the house , even if it did n't quite live up to its opening .
was it a made for tv ' film ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 1:03pm it was made for tv , for channel 4 - it was my big break into film , thanks to walter donoghue and david rose .
at that time , it was virtually impossible to break into film and channel 4 was the lifeboat for myself and many of my contemporaries .
the house was developed first as a performance piece at the ica and various european venues , and i was incorporating film into live performance .
incorporating live music with recorded music.it was a very exciting period for me and i remain excited by the possibilities of live performance and film combined .
it is definitely on my cv - i do n't control the media
clinthackman asks : what 's your favourite willem dafoe performance ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 1:00pm the performance art work he did with theatre x and the wooster group .
they did some very avant garde performance art in the 70s and 80s .
mesm asks : why did you use michael mcdonald 's version of lonely teardrops rather than jackie wilson 's in leaving las vegas ?
and is nic cage a nutter or a professional ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 12:57pm i heard it by chance , in south africa at the end of a long shoot for a commercial .
and i was very taken by it .
it is a live recording and it has great energy .
the band is super tight .
it works .
i did n't even know the original when i heard michael mcdonald 's version.nic cage is a nutter , and used to be much more professional .
he was supposed to be the lead in a feature i was doing last year and he jumped ship in the first week of preproduction .
did n't call , did n't email - just jumped .
and i hear that is becoming a habit .
shame , as he can be a great actor .
artmod asks : you wrote a very inspiring book on digital filmmaking some years ago .
this was back in the days before canon and others introduced reasonably priced dslrs .
do you think the dslr revolution has improved the quality and originality of low budget films ?
guardian contributor mike figgis 19 june 2017 12:54pm in 2000 , i did a q & a conference with steven soderbergh in la , in which we talked about the future of digital versus film .

at that point , the audience which mainly consisted of cinematographers , were convinced that film would be here forever and digital was a kind of a blip.steven and i talked about digital filmmaking and he made the point that there would be 10 times as many bad films on the market as there are now .
i made the point that there would be therefore 10 times as many good films on the market.i think we were both right and both wrong .
it is a big subject .
and it is political in the sense in that it rests on the matter of distribution and film business .

text: british film director mike figgis 's career began in 1988 with the tyneside thriller stormy monday , but it took off internationally two years later with his thriller internal affairs , starring richard gere as a crooked cop and andy garcia as an obsessed investigator .
in 1995 , figgis was nominated for two oscars for leaving las vegas , with his star nicolas cage winning best actor .

since then , figgis has had an experimental and varied career , directing an episode of martin scorsese 's documentary series the blues , the semi-autobiographical film the loss of sexual innocence and the opera lucrezia borgia .

he has made several films incorporating groundbreaking technologies and techniques , with his 2000 film timecode shot simultaneously with four cameras in one take , and presented on a quartered screen .

figgis is also an outspoken critic of mainstream filmmaking , calling the oscars really creepy , and saying of the process of dealing with hollywood studios while making 1993 film mr jones : i 've never in my life experienced anything that was so degrading , so humiliating , so completely lacking in respect .
he also called out the british film industry for [ compromising ] by deciding to be the golly , gosh ' stuttering monarch or the glue-sniffing depressive on a council estate .
his latest work is the book the 36 dramatic situations , named after georges polti 's theory that all drama takes the form of one of this basic repertoire .
figgis read polti 's book while struggling with a film treatment and decided to rework the 150-year-old theory for a modern , film-watching audience .
figgis will be with us on monday 19 june at 1pm bst please post your questions in the comment section below .
